header.title: Satanshimmel Rituale der Schwarzen Magie
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Grimoire Tradition, Black Magic

central_thesis: The book serves as a practical manual for individuals seriously dedicated to black magic, providing detailed instructions for dangerous rituals to achieve personal goals, while explicitly warning away those who are nervous, weak, or superstitious, emphasizing the necessity of precise execution and an unshrinking spirit.

structure_content.summary: This chapter outlines the book's purpose as a guide for serious practitioners of black magic, stressing the importance of thorough study and precise ritual execution. It issues a stern warning to those lacking mental fortitude, indicating the inherent dangers and potential for adverse outcomes if instructions are not followed rigorously.

This section provides detailed instructions for constructing protective magic circles, including optimal size, symbolic inscriptions (names and symbols), and the placement of nine pentagrams with lights (historically human-fat candles, now tealights) outside the circle. It explains the use of salt for its symbolic properties and emphasizes the rule of not leaving or leaning out of the consecrated circle.

The magical sword is introduced as an instrument for dissolution and defense, associated with the element Air. Guidelines are given for its appropriate length, material (wood, horn, or non-conductive metal for the hilt), and its function as a 'lightning rod' to deflect negative energies.

The altar is described as a storage place for magical tools, ideally made of oak wood and reaching the practitioner's navel height. Dr. Dee's double-cube altar design, featuring ten squares on its outer surface for magical symbols, is presented as a model, with the suggestion for practitioners to develop their own symbolic system.

The magical bell is a crucial accessory for expelling or summoning spirits, made from a specific blend of seven metals consecrated under favorable planetary alignments. Its sound is believed to be intolerable to spirits, and its clapper was historically made from human bone. The text includes an incantation for its consecration.

This section lists additional necessary equipment, all to be new and unused. It details their elemental associations: candelabras and candles for Fire, a skull or graveyard earth for Earth, a censer for Air (symbolizing materialization), and a water glass or crystal ball for Water (used in destructive rituals to absorb negative energy).

structure_content.chapter_title: Über die Verschiedenen Arten der Magie
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines various forms of magic: Black Magic (Goetie) for personal gain, harm, and summoning demons/Satan; White Magic for healing, positive outcomes, and invoking angels/good spirits. It distinguishes High Magic (communication with higher self) from Low Magic (practical concerns) and explains the 'Path of the Right Hand' (light, truth) versus the 'Path of the Left Hand' (darkness, evil). Sympathy and Contact Magic are also described as fundamental principles.

A method for cursing an individual, involving the creation of a 'witch's garland' from a string with knots and black feathers. The curse is spoken with intense concentration on the desired misfortune, including specific incantations to Satan, and the garland is hidden near the target.

This ritual describes inducing illness by making a wax effigy of the target, attaching personal items (e.g., hair), and binding a spider-poisoned thread around the effigy's limb corresponding to the desired location of pain, accompanied by an incantation to infernal powers.

This image magic ritual involves creating a wax effigy of the target, inserting personal items (preferably hair), and entering a state of intense rage. An oak-wood spear is then thrust into the effigy while it is roasted over fire, accompanied by a reversed 'Misere mei, Deus' incantation to inflict fear and eventually death.

A bewitchment ritual using consecrated nails (fumigated with Saturn-appropriate incense and evil spirits invoked) and a wax figure representing the target, to which their hair or clothing is attached. The nails are repeatedly stuck into the figure over three days, with curses uttered to cause unknown illness and eventual death.

A variation of image magic where a wax figure of the target, adorned with personal items, is pierced with nails, needles, or sharp oak-wood stakes in a state of rage. The figure is then consecrated in Satan's name and buried under the target's doorstep to cause severe, persistent pain throughout their body.

This ritual aims to punish liars, thieves, or wrongdoers. It involves consecrating a magic wand with a specific inscription, burning frankincense, writing the target's name with interspersed letters on paper, turning around the paper three times while reciting an incantation, then burning the paper over a bowl while striking the bowl seven times with the wand, concentrating on the desired punishment.

The footprint is considered magically powerful, linked to the individual's soul. Manipulating it can affect the person or animal it belongs to; e.g., driving a coffin nail into it causes death, throwing it into flowing water causes wasting, or hot ashes cause burning. It can also be used to undo bewitchment by using earth from the presumed sorcerer's doorstep.

This section details methods for healing by symbolically 'burying' the illness. This involves burying body parts (hair, nails, teeth, urine) or objects rubbed on the diseased area in a secluded spot, especially at crossroads at midnight, ensuring no daylight touches the burial site, and repeating the process over three consecutive days.

structure_content.chapter_title: Um den Urheber einer Behexung zu erkennen
structure_content.summary: To identify the source of bewitchment, the practitioner is advised to visit a graveyard between eleven and midnight, taking earth from a freshly dug grave. Upon returning, loud noises will be heard, and the bewitcher's house will be revealed by a specific sound emanating from it, but the practitioner must not look back.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gegen allerlei zauberische Einflüsse, Schaden und Zustände
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides traditional remedies against magical influences and harm. It suggests applying St. John's Wort oil and crushed juniper to affected areas, or boiling juniper with onions for external application. Drinking juniper seed or St. John's Wort concoctions, especially juniper berry essence mixed with oil and St. John's Wort water, is also recommended for those possessed or bewitched.

structure_content.chapter_title: Um ein Tier vor Behexung zu schützen
structure_content.summary: A protective ritual for animals against bewitchment, involving speaking an incantation ('HEREGO GOMET HUNC GUERIDANS SESSERANT DELIBERANT AMEI') over a cup of salt. The practitioner then walks three times around the animal, starting from the East and following the sun's path, sprinkling pinches of salt on it while repeating the incantation.

To avert bewitchment, carrying a Venus or Moon talisman in a salt-filled pouch is suggested. If a bewitching substance (e.g., wax figure) is found, it should be burned or destroyed in flowing water with a counter-incantation. If the substance cannot be found, a counter-effigy of the perpetrator is made, adorned with seven talismans, and elemental spirits are invoked over it daily for seven days before burning it.

The evil eye is described as a powerful spiritual force emanating from the soul, capable of causing decay, misfortune, and death in humans, plants, and animals. It is characterized by a fixed, piercing gaze and can be wielded by both ill-intentioned individuals and demons. Eye amulets are recommended as effective countermeasures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Ritual zur Verbannung von Spukgeistern aus Gebäuden
structure_content.summary: To banish poltergeists from a building, a new broom and a specially prepared light are used to sweep the entire house. When the light extinguishes at the poltergeist's location, a specific incantation to Astaroth or other princes of poltergeists is recited. This is followed by fumigating the entire house with juniper and buckthorn wood to force the spirit out through a window into a wild, desolate area.

This section provides a recipe for a special light used in spirit summoning and binding rituals. It involves combining black goat's blood, dragon's blood, sulfur, frankincense, and mastic in a crucible. This 'light' is prepared during the day, specifically at the hour of Luna, and used with a binding incantation, tied with a rope, once the spirit appears.

This ritual is designed to awaken or strengthen love, or to bring back a lost partner. It should be performed about an hour before meeting the person, focusing intensely on the desired outcome. The practitioner writes an incantation ('BADDOU, EIQASCH, WADOUD, ARQASCH') over food with a magic wand and recites an invocation to BADDOU to unite the individuals, repeating the ritual for at least seven, or up to twenty-one, consecutive days.

This section provides recipes for 'flying ointments,' concoctions of narcotic plants (e.g., deadly nightshade, poppy, hemlock, henbane) and animal fats (e.g., children's fat, toad fat). These ointments, when rubbed on the body, are intended to induce hallucinatory states that allow practitioners to experience the Witches' Sabbath and interact with astral beings.

This chapter explores the magical properties of various gemstones, classifying them as either benevolent or malevolent. It details specific stones like amethyst (against drunkenness, for friendship), amber (for healing throat and earaches), garnet (protection against evil and lightning), jasper (for stomach ailments), carnelian (protection against poison and accidents), lapis lazuli (for friendship, healing, and sleep), moonstone (for fertility, but unlucky), opal (unlucky, evil eye), ruby (amulet against poison, sorrow, evil spirits), sapphire (against bewitchment, illness), emerald (protection from deceit, healing eyes/kidneys), topaz (prophetic powers, against night terrors), and turquoise (against evil eye, murder, changing color with illness).

This section categorizes various methods of divination based on the tools or elements used. It lists diverse practices such as Aeromancy (clouds), Aleuromancy (flour), Lithomancy (stones), Pyromancy (fire), Hydromancy (water), Cartomancy (cards), Necromancy (the dead), and many others, illustrating the breadth of divinatory arts.

Detailed instructions for pendulum divination are provided, including environmental preparation (removing metals, electronics), choosing and preparing a pendulum (small, pointed, 25-100g weight, 15-35cm length), and meditating to prevent self-doubt. It explains how to interpret pendulum movements (lines, circles, ellipses, stillness) to determine 'yes/no' answers, locate objects, diagnose illnesses, assess compatibility, or evaluate the favorability of items, using diagnostic tables.

This chapter defines amulets as passive protective items and talismans as active tools for personal gain. It details their creation, emphasizing inscription of magical words/symbols on materials like clay, wood, stone, or metals, using specific inks (rosewater, orange blossom water, blood of a white dove). It also discusses the ABRACADABRA word square and its use, and outlines methods for consecrating and maintaining their power through various actions like warming, fumigation, spitting, breathing, and blood-sprinkling.

structure_content.chapter_title: Wie Amulette und Talismane durch Weihung wirkungsvoll gemacht werden
structure_content.summary: This section elaborates on the consecration process for amulets and talismans. It details the use of planet-assigned metals (e.g., copper for Venus, iron for Mars) and inks (black ink or dove's blood). Consecration is most effective during the 14 waxing days of the lunar month, starting with purification via incense, followed by charging through focused willpower and breath, imbuing the object with desired properties. Verification with a pendulum is recommended, and the text includes diagrams of efficacious magical signs.

A Venus talisman is described for attracting love and fostering reconciliation. It consists of a round copper plate, depicting Venus with Cupid on one side and a magic square on the other. It should be consecrated on a Friday when Venus is favorably aligned with Jupiter.

The Seal of Solomon, a hexagram formed by two intertwined triangles, is presented as an ancient and powerful symbol used by King Solomon to command spirits, humans, and animals. The upward-pointing triangle represents good (God), and the downward-pointing one represents evil (Devil). It is commonly used on magical attire and in occult texts, also serving as a talisman for protection on journeys and against harmful influences.

Runes are introduced as ancient Germanic script and symbols of cosmic radiation, originating in the second century CE. They function as talismans, amulets, and divinatory tools, meant to be carved into metal, bone, or stone. The chapter explains the individual magical properties of several runes, such as 'Fa' for perseverance, 'Ur' for self-understanding, 'Thorn' for will, 'Os' for breath/self-awareness, 'Rit' for protection against injustice, 'Ka' for artistic and magical abilities, 'Hagall' as the supreme rune encompassing all others and used for both positive and negative magic, 'Sig' for strength/victory, 'Tyr' for wealth, 'Bar' and 'Laf' for specific talismanic uses, 'Man' for spiritual/physical strength, 'Yr' not for talismans, 'Eh' for binding two people, and 'Gibor' with minor magical effects.

This brief section introduces the Necronomicon, originally titled 'Al Azif,' as an Arabic grimoire of black magic attributed to Abdul Alhazred. It is stated to contain numerous incantations and seals for summoning spirits.

structure_content.chapter_title: Der Exorzismus BARRA EDINNAZU gegen Geister, die den Kreis angreifen
structure_content.summary: An incantation, 'ZI ANNA KANPA! ZI KI A KANPA! GALLU BARRA! NAMTAR BARRA!' and similar phrases, is provided for the exorcism of hostile spirits attempting to breach the magic circle during a ritual.

A ritual to confuse enemies and neutralize malicious sorcery. It involves tying ten knots in a cord, untying one knot for each line of the provided incantation, and then throwing the cord into flames. The incantation, 'SSALMANI-IAANA PAGRI TAPQIDA DUPPIRA!' and its variations, is translated as 'You have given my images to the dead, return! You have seen my images with the dead, return!' etc., signifying the reversal of magical actions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Zauberspruch, um die Liebe einer Frau zu gewinnen
structure_content.summary: A love spell, where a specific incantation ('MUNUS SIGSIGGA AG BARA YE INNIN AGGISCH XASCHXUR GISCHNU URMA SCHAZIGABARAYE ZIGASCHUBBA NA AGSISCHAMAZIGA NAMZA YE INNIN DURRE ESCH AKKI UGUAGBAANDAGUB!') must be sung three times over an apple, which is then offered to the desired person.

structure_content.chapter_title: Fluch, um dem Feind eine Krankheit anzuhexen
structure_content.summary: A curse to inflict illness on an enemy, requiring an incantation ('AZAG GALRA SAGBI MU UNNA TE NAMTAR GALRA ZIBI MU UNNA TE' and similar phrases, meaning 'Disease of the throat unto him! Disease of the eye unto him!') to be spoken over a wax doll representing the target.

structure_content.chapter_title: Der Sturz des Satans und der anderen abtrünnigen Engel aus dem Himmel
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the theological origins of Satan and fallen angels, detailing their rebellion against God's plan for humanity, their irreversible choice for evil, and their eternal damnation in Hell. It describes Satan's fall from the highest angelic ranks (Satanael becoming Satan) and the subsequent hierarchy of evil spirits.

This section describes the hierarchical structure of evil spirits, noting their various ranks (chieftains, servants) and seven dwelling places in Hell. It also presents Agrippa's classification of demons into nine grades, detailing their functions (e.g., lying, teaching evil arts, revenge, imitation of miracles, causing storms, strife, blasphemy) and their principal figures (Beelzebub, Python, Belial, Asmodi, Satan, Meirim, Appolio/Abaddon, Astharoth, Mammon).

Trithemius's system categorizes demons into six types: Fire spirits (highest, no human interaction), Air spirits (cause storms, deceptive), Earth spirits (dwell in forests, caves, deceive, induce madness, provide answers in crystals), Water spirits (rivers, lakes, wrathful, appear as females/animals), Underground spirits (most malevolent, cause fear), and Light-shy spirits (nocturnal, obscure, malevolent). Each type has distinct characteristics and preferred manifestations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Rangliste der höllischen Dämonen nach der Zauberliteratur des 17. und 18. Jahrhunderts
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a comprehensive listing of infernal demons according to 17th and 18th-century grimoires, including their ranks: King (Lucifer), Viceroy (Belial), Governors (Satan, Beelzebub, Astaroth, Pluto), Grand Princes (Aziel, Mephistophiles, Marbuel, Ariel, Aniguel, Anifel, Barfael), Grand Councilors (Abbadon, Chamus, Milea, Lapasis, Merapis), Secretary of State (Milpeza), and Familiar Spirits (Chinicham, Pimpam, Masa, Lissa, Dromdrom, Lomha, Palasa, Naufa, Lima, Pora, Saya, Wunsolay).

structure_content.chapter_title: Die Hierarchie der Dämonen nach Sebastien Michaelis Admirable History (1612)
structure_content.summary: Sebastien Michaelis's hierarchy of demons is presented in three orders, linking specific demons to the seven deadly sins and corresponding angelic orders. The First Hierarchy includes Beelzebub (Pride), Leviathan (Faith), Asmodeus (Lust), Balberith (Blasphemy/Murder), Astaroth (Vanity/Sloth), Verrine (Impatience), Gressil (Impurity), and Sonneillon (Hate). The Second Hierarchy covers Carreau (Mercilessness), Carnivean (Obscenity), Oeillet (Wealth), Rosier (Love), and Verrier (Disobedience). The Third Hierarchy lists Belial (Arrogance), Olivier (Cruelty), and Iuvart (Possession).

This section explores the etymology and symbolic representations of Satan, originating from Hebrew as 'adversary.' In Islam, he is Shaitan, responsible for magic. In the Old Testament, he is an accuser and tempter. After his fall, he becomes the Prince and God of this World, embodying the principle of evil. The text explains Satan's association with the North, misfortune, and the North Wind, reflecting his destructive nature.

Lucifer, meaning 'light-bringer,' is depicted as originally the morning star before his fall from heaven, transforming into the embodiment of darkness. He is presented as a higher-ranking demon than Satan, associated with pride, vanity, and arrogance, contrasting with Satan's wrath and greed. Lucifer brings fire and light, inspiring passion and creativity (music, art, poetry), but also illusion. He presides over the East, and Monday is his day for summoning, appearing as a beautiful, proud, and melancholic youth.

Beelzebub, 'Lord of the Flies,' is described as a prince of the realm of darkness and a demon of Saturn. He was one of the first angels to fall from the Seraphim order, next to Lucifer and Leviathan. In the New Testament, he is identified as the chief of demons. His exorcism supposedly causes a fly to emerge from the possessed. In the 'Dictionnaire infernal,' he is depicted as a large stinging fly bearing symbols of death.

Leviathan, 'the Twisted One,' is presented as the demon of envy. In the Old Testament, he personifies all forces of misfortune and is described as a monstrous, scaly creature. He is also identified as the Dragon of Chaos and an apocalyptic enemy of God.

Belial, meaning 'wickedness' or 'without a master,' is a Hebrew demon associated with depravity and the underworld. In the 'Hexenhammer,' he is described as rebellious against authority. The Old Testament uses 'men of Belial' to denote evil individuals. Belial appears as a black, pointy-eared devil with a bird's face at his rear and hooves or claws.

Abbadon, meaning 'destruction' in Hebrew and 'destroyer' in Greek (Apollyon), is the angel of the abyss and personification of the realm of the dead. In the Old Testament, it initially refers to a place of destruction. In the New Testament, particularly Revelation, he is described as an infernal angel, the 'King of Locusts' and 'King of the Abyss.'

Azazel is identified as a desert demon from Israelite folklore. He is associated with the scapegoat ritual on the Day of Atonement, where the high priest symbolically transferred the sins of the people onto a goat sent into the wilderness to Azazel.

This section classifies demons by their functions, indicating which spirits to invoke for specific purposes: for love and relationships (Asmodeus, Astarte, Lilith, Sallos), hate, revenge, and war (Abbadon, Andras, Belphegor, Satan), life and healing (Baalberith, Belial, Leviathan, Rimmon), money, prosperity, and luck (Asmodeus, Beelzebub, Mammon, Lucifuge Rofocale), and knowledge, secrets, and magic (Abbadon, Belial, Leviathan, Paimon, Python).

structure_content.chapter_title: Namen von Geistern, die berufen werden können
structure_content.summary: Based on Abraham of Worms, this chapter lists numerous noble and skilled spirits that can be summoned for various purposes. It categorizes spirits associated with Astaroth and Asmodi (e.g., Amamil, Orienell, Tinira) and Beelzebub (e.g., Altanor, Armasia, Corilon), providing extensive lists of names for invocation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Liste der Namen einiger gefallener Engel
structure_content.summary: This list enumerates fallen angels, estimated to number 1,333,306,660 in the 15th century, who rebelled against God and were cast from Heaven. These spirits inhabit air, lakes, rivers, seas, and earth. Notable names include Abbadona, Adramelec, Asmodeus, Astaroth, Beelzebub, Belial, Caim, Dagon, Leviathan, Lucifer, Mammon, Mephistopheles, Paimon, Satan, and many others.

Similar to demons, angels also possess a hierarchy with nine orders grouped into three hierarchies: Seraphim, Cherubim, Thrones (First); Dominions, Principalities, Powers (Second); Virtues, Archangels, Angels (Third). It names nine superior angels (Metanon, Orphaniel, Zaphiel, Zadkiel, Camael, Raphael, Haniel, Michael, Gabriel) and four archangels governing the four cardinal directions and winds (Michael for East/East Wind, Raphael for West/West Wind, Gabriel for North/North Wind, Uriel for South/South Wind). It also assigns specific angels to the four elements (Cherub for Air, Tharsis for Water, Ariel for Earth, Seruph for Fire).

Angels are diverse beings, classified into nine orders, which also reflects the hierarchy of fallen angels. They exist between eternity and time, interacting with the latter only for their tasks. Not bound by space, they can move instantaneously and occupy one place at a time. Angels possess a degree of power, able to move matter and other spirits, but not without limits. They are not omniscient, having varying intellects and innate knowledge. Their communication occurs via 'Angelic Language.' Angels possess free will, making their choices (good or evil) eternal and immutable, as demonstrated by the division during the Fall.

This chapter explains that demons are fallen angels whose nature, though corrupted, retains its essential angelic qualities like incorporeality and independence from space and time. Their will, however, is entirely fixed on evil, even if they pretend otherwise. Demons, sharing the same origin as 'light angels,' can sometimes be confused with them. The text emphasizes that there are no 'neutral' demons; they are either wholly good or wholly evil.

structure_content.chapter_title: Wie sich die Erscheinungen der Engel von den Erscheinungen der Dämonen unterscheiden
structure_content.summary: This section details the visual distinctions between angels and demons. Archangels appear with accompanying angels, while angels generally manifest as beautiful youths with grace and calm, and radiate light. Demons, in contrast, typically appear in hideous, animalistic forms (bears, lions, dogs, dragons) and are accompanied by harmful creatures. They often use false images to deceive, exhibit stormy movements, and their light is dimmer, lacking the splendor of angels. The size of their appearance corresponds to their power, but unlike angels, demons may vary in their manifested size.

This chapter provides a detailed protocol for summoning demons. The ritual specifies timing (Monday/Tuesday or Friday/Saturday night), location (secluded, eerie places like ruins or old graveyards), and attire (black). Preparations include laying out tools (candles, sword, censer), drawing a circle on the ground, and a triangle (with a blood offering) where the demon will appear. The procedure involves lighting nine tealights, consecrating the circle, burning frankincense and storax, concentrating on the demon's seal, and reciting the incantation while holding a sword. If the demon resists, threats of divine power and banishment are used, culminating in the demon's visible appearance and subsequent dismissal.

structure_content.chapter_title: Die Beschwörung des Lucifuge zur Beschaffung von Reichtum
structure_content.summary: This ritual targets Lucifuge Rofocale for wealth acquisition. It involves cutting a hazelnut branch with a new knife at sunrise two days prior, then going to a secluded spot with a bloodstone and two consecrated candles. A triangle is drawn with the bloodstone, candles are placed, and divine names are inscribed. The practitioner then stands in the triangle with the hazelnut staff, calling upon Lucifer, Beelzebub, and Astaroth to aid in summoning Lucifuge without stench. A pact for wealth is then offered, with negotiation over the soul and time. The ritual emphasizes firmness and a specific incantation using powerful divine names to compel appearance. A pact is written in blood and exchanged after Lucifuge appears and reveals the treasure, then the spirit is dismissed.

This short chapter notes that summoning formulas are ancient, with their texts often corrupted over time due to transcription errors, making full translation difficult. However, it states that these formulas retain their magical efficacy despite textual inaccuracies, having accumulated inherent power through prolonged use.

structure_content.chapter_title: Magische Beschwörung mit dem sogenannten Schlüssel Salomonis
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces a powerful magical summoning from the 'Key of Solomon,' revered for its mastery over the underworld. The text emphasizes that while the original formulas are in Hebrew, they are presented here in Latin characters. The chapter provides the full invocation, 'PER ADONAI ELOIM, ADONAI JEI^VA, ADONAI SABAOTH,' along with explanations of the divine names used (e.g., El meaning 'Mighty God,' Elohim as 'Creator Gods,' Sebaoth as 'Hosts,' Adonai as 'Lord,' Yah as 'Praise Him,' Sadai as 'Distributor,' Tetragrammaton as 'JHWH').

structure_content.chapter_title: Eine einfache Art, die bösen Mächte zu beschwören, ist folgende:
structure_content.summary: A simple method for summoning evil powers involves sacrificing a black hen that has never laid an egg at a crossroads at midnight. The hen must be cut into two equal parts while reciting the incantation 'Eloim. Essaim, frugativi et appellavi!'. The practitioner then faces East, kneels, and performs a grand invocation while holding a large cypress staff, which is said to immediately cause the spirit to appear.

structure_content.chapter_title: Beschwöruugsfurmelu und Siegel der Geister aus Herpentils Schwarze Magie aus dem Jahr 1505
structure_content.summary: This section presents specific summoning formulas and seals from 'Herpentil's Black Magic from the Year 1505.' It includes a required phrase upon entering the magic circle and detailed invocations for various demon princes: Amazeroth (three distinct formulas), Phisazeroth, Reymonzorackon, Amileckar, and Alenzozoff. Each invocation is accompanied by instructions for greeting the spirit once it appears and specific farewells. The text also includes the visual seals for Phisazeroth, Reymonzorackon, Amileckar, and Alenzozoff.

This chapter provides specific formulas for summoning elemental spirits. For air spirits, one faces East and recites 'Spiritus dei ferebatur super aquas...' (using Pentagrammaton). For water spirits, one faces West and recites 'Fiat firmamentum in medio aquarum...' (creatura aquae). For fire spirits, one faces South, throws salt, frankincense, camphor, and sulfur into the fire, and invokes Michael, Samael, and Anael. For earth spirits, one faces North and sprinkles water on the earth while performing an appropriate fumigation.

This section explains a pact with the Devil as a long-term binding agreement for service in exchange for magical aid during life, with the understanding that the practitioner will serve the spirit in the afterlife. The pact involves writing mutual obligations on two blood-stained documents (from the left arm), one for the spirit and one to be consumed by the magician.

The text presents an example of a Devil's Pact attributed to Aleister Crowley. This pact includes an oath of fealty 'By the huge height of heaven above I swear to thee to be thy love,' and a renunciation of Christian baptismal grace, pledging body, mind, and soul to 'Satan's bands' in service to 'the beast and thy control.'

This section provides historical context for the Faust legend and presents the actual text of a pact with Mephistopheles, supposedly signed by Johannes Faustus. In this pact, Faust pledges his soul, body, flesh, blood, and goods to the spirit for 24 years in exchange for knowledge and power, specifically 'to speculate the elements.' He renounces the Heavenly Host and all humans, signing with his own blood, mind, thoughts, and will.

structure_content.chapter_title: Wie man den Teufelspakt wieder aufkündigt
structure_content.summary: To revoke a devil's pact, the text describes a ritual involving the sacrifice of a lamb on a Friday in the name of God. The lamb's blood is then used to draw a large circle, within which specific Christian phrases from the Gospels (e.g., 'God so loved the world,' 'The Word became Flesh,' 'The blood of Jesus Christ') are written. The circle must be consecrated with the 'Haupt-Kreis-Weihung' to bind all devils, ensuring no harm can befall the practitioner.

structure_content.chapter_title: Die Planetengeister, ihre Orte, ihre Gestalt und Siegel
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the seven planetary spirits (Aratron, Phaleg, Phul, Bethor, Ophiel, Hagith, Och) from 'Arbatel, de magia veterum.' It details their domains, what they govern, their physical forms or manifestations (e.g., Aratron transforms things into stone, Phaleg grants martial dignity, Phul transforms metals into silver), their associated days for summoning, and the appropriate incense for each (e.g., storax for Aratron on Saturday, sulfur for Phaleg on Tuesday). Each spirit's seal is also depicted.

This section explains that good spirits are easier to summon due to their benevolent nature and appear when invoked with good intentions. They are summoned using holy names, divine power, sacred symbols, and sacraments, and their invocations are considered the most potent. It emphasizes the importance of studying the invocation, reciting it from memory in a firm, natural voice, and choosing the right time (waxing moon) and a clean, secluded location. It provides Latin incantations for archangels Michael, Gabriel, Samael, Raphael, Anael, and Cassiel, and notes the appropriate days and incense for each.

This chapter illustrates various simple and composite geometric signs considered representative of good spirits. These include a simple point, a circular point, a star-shaped point, slanted lines, horizontal lines, straight lines, curved lines, wavy lines, toothed lines, straight incision lines, inserted lines, cruciform double lines, complete and abbreviated circles, and inherent, adherent, and separated letters.

This section visually presents various seals and sigils of specific demons, including Alger, Nambroth, Nabam, Acham, Astaroth, Marbuel (depicted as a ten-year-old boy, swift as an arrow), Barbuel (lord of seas and waters), Aziabel (a great spirit appearing as a small child, ruler over the right hand), and Anifel. A large illustration of 'The Prince of Demons' with his servants' seals is also included, along with signatures from 'Le Véritable Dragon rouge' (1522) for major figures like Lucifer, Beelzebub, and Lucifuge.

Necromancy is explained as the art of making the dead subservient to answer questions truthfully. It notes that departed souls sometimes appear unbidden, particularly if they committed evil, failed in life, or hold secrets. Apparitions are often unnatural and unintelligible, unable to move their legs, and may repeat past actions or frighten the living. Rarely do souls appear directly; typically, angels or demons mediate, taking on visible, tangible, but air-like forms, and can act without the deceased's knowledge.

structure_content.chapter_title: Methode der Totenbeschwörung zur sichtbaren Erscheinung Verstorbener
structure_content.summary: This method for necromancy, aimed at making the deceased visibly appear, involves preparing a clean room, creating a wax figure of the deceased (with personal items), a light source made from specific animal and plant components (e.g., goat blood, dragon's blood). During the ritual, the practitioner invokes the person's name, identifies with them, and commands them to appear, repeating the invocation multiple times until the desired, increasingly lifelike, apparition occurs.

A necromantic ritual performed at night in a clean room. It involves creating a wax figure of the deceased, to which specific grave earth is attached. The practitioner burns specific incense (frankincense, myrrh) and recites incantations. After the spirit appears, it is questioned about the past, present, and future. The ritual warns against fear or interruption, as the spirit may become hostile, and describes the light source and fumigation needed.

This chapter provides recipes for incense used in necromantic rituals to facilitate the materialization (densification) of astral bodies, allowing the deceased to take on a temporary physical form without drawing on the summoner's own vital substances. Recipes include white frankincense mixed with fine flour, egg, milk, rose honey, and oil, or grated aloe wood mixed with ambergris, and powdered bone mixed with lamb's blood.

structure_content.chapter_title: Methode der Totenbeschwörung nach der Vorschrift des Trithemius
structure_content.summary: This detailed necromantic method from Trithemius's 1506 work involves sacrificing a white rooster and hen, mixing their blood with water, and using this to create three cakes from white wheat flour. Angelic names are inscribed on these cakes, which are then exposed to the sun and moon. This ritual aims to enable communication with stars, the moon, or the dead, and involves specific incantations to angels and the deceased, culminating in the spirit's appearance from the earth, and its subsequent dismissal.

This section introduces Eliphas Lévi (Alphonse-Louis Constant), a French occultist and former Catholic theologian whose work on Kabbalah, magic, and Tarot significantly influenced Western occultism. Lévi's three fundamental laws of magic are presented: the Law of Willpower (supernatural force from humans), the Law of Astral Light (a pervasive substance enabling psychic effects), and the Principle of Correspondence (microcosm/macrocosm, enabling influence through manipulation of images or external elements, and summoning inner representations).

This chapter introduces Abraham the Jew (Abraham von Worms), author of 'The Book of the Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage' (1307). The book, which appeared in German in 1450, describes Abraham's encounter with the hermit Abramelin and details a system of Theurgy (divine magic) for interacting with divine and demonic beings. It includes magical squares and demon names. The text notes its influence on orders like the Golden Dawn and Aleister Crowley, and Crowley's failed attempt to invoke his guardian angel due to fear.

This section introduces Cornelius Agrippa, a polymath (physician, lawyer, theologian, magician) whose main work, 'De Occulta Philosophia' (1510), theorized that God governs the world through spirits, the hierarchical structure of the universe, and the animistic nature of celestial bodies. He believed in attractive/repulsive forces and the microcosm/macrocosm principle. The text also mentions the legend of Agrippa's demonic familiar, a black dog named 'Monsieur,' which allegedly inspired Goethe's Faustian character.

This section introduces Dr. John Dee, a renowned English mathematician, astrologer, alchemist, and magician. It describes his crucial collaboration with Edward Kelley (1502), a medium with whom he conducted spiritistic sessions using crystal balls and wax tablets inscribed with magical symbols. Dee's reception of the Enochian language (or 'Angelic Language') through Kelley in 1582, and the subsequent '19 Enochian Keys,' are highlighted as foundational to their work, later adopted by Aleister Crowley.

This chapter introduces Aleister Crowley, a prominent English occultist and poet, founder of several orders (e.g., Argenteum Astrum). It discusses his pseudonyms ('Master Therion,' 'Frater Perdurabo'), his involvement with the Golden Dawn, and his publication of 'Liber Al vel Legis,' which proclaimed a new Aeon ('Eoquinox of the Gods') based on the laws 'Every man and every woman is a star' and 'Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law.' It recounts his establishment of 'The Abbey of Thelema' in Cefalu, Sicily, where he practiced controversial rituals, and his difficulties controlling summoned Abramelin demons. It also mentions his Tarot card creation with Frieda Harris and his impoverished death.

This section introduces Anton Szandor LaVey (born Howard Stanton Levey), an American occultist. It highlights his role in establishing the 'First Church of Satan' in San Francisco in 1966 and his influential works, 'The Satanic Bible' (1969), 'The Compleat Witch' (1971), and 'The Satanic Rituals' (1972).

This chapter details the 19 Enochian Keys, a series of invocations in the Enochian language, which is described as the language of angels. These keys were dictated to Dr. John Dee and Edward Kelley by the angel Nalvage (or Gabriel). The text provides German translations of several key invocations, such as 'I placed my feet in the South' (Fourth Key), 'The mighty sounds have reached the third angle' (Fifth Key), and 'Oh, ye Heavens that dwell in the First Aethyr' (Nineteenth Key), revealing their purpose to command elements, reveal secrets, and bring forth various entities or influences.

The concluding chapter reiterates the importance of careful consideration and precise execution of all rituals. It assures practitioners that by following the advice, they will undoubtedly benefit. However, it issues a final warning that disregarding the instructions will lead to terrible misfortune, ending with the assertion: 'There is no law, except do what you will.'

key_concepts.definition: Supernatural work for one's own benefit, encompassing harmful magic and achieving goals with the help of demons and Satan.
Synonymous with black magic, aimed at destroying people or property and negatively impacting others' lives.
Magical practices performed with healing or otherwise positive intent, seeking assistance from angels or good spirits and warding off demons or evil.
A form of magic focused on communication with one's personal guardian angel or higher self.
Practical or domestic magic aimed at concerns such as finding a new lover, attracting luck, or improving employment.
Practices serving a selfless purpose, associated with light and truth, followed by white magicians.
Practices pursuing personal goals, associated with darkness, evil, and black magic, followed by black magicians.
Based on the law of similarity, where damaging an image of a person can simultaneously harm the original.
Based on the principle that things and persons that have been in contact maintain a secret connection thereafter.
Magical acts whose sequence is precisely prescribed by scriptures or secret traditions; exact adherence to the ritual is crucial for success.
Another term for ritual magic, emphasizing the transcendental experience during the magical act.
The summoning of spirits, including the summoning of devils. Necromancy is a variant of theurgy.
The ancient art of summoning the dead to gain knowledge, where the dead are compelled to answer truthfully.
The safest means of protection against damage from spirits. Circles are customized with names and symbols based on the nature of the spirit, time, and place.
Represents magical will; used for attracting, especially for summoning spirits and demons. Made from a straight branch, consecrated over seven days at new moon.
Attributed to the element of Air, used for dissolving and deflecting. Its length should allow the tip to touch the ground with the hilt at hand height. Functions like a lightning rod.
Used for storing magical equipment, ideally made of oak wood and reaching the practitioner's navel height. Dr. Dee's double-cube altar design is presented as an example.
An important accessory for expelling or summoning spirits, made from a blend of seven metals, consecrated and rung to deter or compel spirits. Its sound is believed to be unbearable for spirits.
Fallen angels who maintain their incorporeal nature but whose will is solely fixed on evil. They appear in hideous or animalistic forms and often deceive.
Divine beings with a hierarchy of nine orders. They possess free will and intellect, and their appearances are typically beautiful, graceful, and radiant.
Passively acting objects imbued with magical powers, worn or placed to ward off harmful influences.
Actively acting objects used for self-serving purposes, such as bringing luck or success, often worn visibly.
Ancient Germanic script and symbols of cosmic radiation, used as talismans, amulets, for divination, and various magical purposes.
An occult grimoire, originally titled 'Al Azif,' containing invocations and seals for summoning numerous spirits, attributed to Abdul Alhazred.
A set of 19 invocations in the Enochian language, received by Dr. John Dee and Edward Kelley, believed to be the language of angels, used for commanding various entities.

practical_system.description: The book presents a practical, operative magical system rooted in ceremonial black magic and grimoire traditions. It emphasizes meticulous preparation, including ritual tools, timing, and mental concentration. The system involves creating protective spaces (magic circles), crafting symbolic effigies and talismans, and performing detailed invocations and curses. It outlines methods for communicating with and commanding various spirits—demonic, elemental, planetary, and angelic—for a wide range of purposes, from wealth and love to inflicting illness and banishing poltergeists. Pacts with infernal entities and necromancy are also covered as advanced practices, with specific instructions on how to enter and, if necessary, renounce such agreements.

relevant_quotes.text: Ich gebe allen nervösen, schwachen, hysterischen, abergläubischen und dummen Menschen den Rat, dieses Buch niemals zu öffnen, oder, falls sie es geöffnet haben, es an dieser Stelle zu schliessen. Diesen würde nur alles dunkel und verwickelt vorkommen, und der Pöbel reagiert erfahrungsgemäß auf Dinge, die sich seinem kleinen Geist entziehen, mit Spott, Entrüstung und Empörung. Zudem sind die beschriebenen Rituale nicht gefahrlos und somit ungeeignet für jene, welche nicht auf der festen Grundlage eines unerschrockenen Geistes stehen. Wer nicht alles genau befolgt, wird bald feststellen wie leicht etwas zu seinem Nachteil ausschlagen kann. Ich habe Euch gewarnt, und somit habe ich meine Pflicht erfüllt.

Ich Verfluche und Vernichte dich (Name)! Ich Verfluche dein Leben und Vernichte dein Wesen! Bei der Macht des Satans verfluche ich dein Dasein und verbanne dich in die tiefste Hölle! Falle hinein in fürchterliche Qualen! O Satan, höre mich, die Erde soll ihn ersticken, denn mein sind ihre Kräfte! Das Feuer soll ihn quälen, denn mein ist seine Magie. Und die Luft soll nicht um ihn wehen, noch soll das Wasser ihn kühlen, sondern da sei nicht auszuhaltende Qual! Die Kraft meines Fluches soll für immer und ewig auf ihm sein und Gott soll ihn nicht hören, noch ihm jemals helfen. Der Fluch soll ihn Verfolgen auf immer und ewig!
Vorderseite: „AGLA ON TETRAGRAMATON" Auf der Rückseite: „EGO ALPHA ET OMEGA"
Ich verspreche dem grossen Lucifuge, ihn nach zwanzig Jahren für alle Schätze, die er mir gegeben hat, zu belohnen.
O grosser Lucifuge, ich bin mit dir zufrieden. Ich werde dich jetzt entlassen, gehe in Frieden, du darfst gehen, wohin du willst, aber ohne allen Lärm und Gestank.

I here renounce all grace or chrism that I have gotten in baptism. I bind my blood in Satan's bands All this, that lieth betwixt mine hands To thee, the beast and thy control I pledge me: body, mind and soul.

Ich, Johannes Faustus D. bekenne mit meiner eigen Handt öffentlich, zu einer Bestetigung, und in krafft dieses Briefts: Nach dem ich mir fürgenommen, die Elementa zu speculieren, und aber aus den Gaaben, so mit von oben herab beschert, und gnedig mitgetheilt wordten, solche Geschicklichkeit in meinem Kopf, nicht befinde, und solches von den Menschen nicht erlehrnen mag, so hab ich gegenwertigen gesamtem Geist, der sich Mephostophiles nennt, ein Diener des hellischen Prinzen in Orient, mich untergeben, auch denselbigen, mich solches zu berichten und zu lehren, mir erwehlet, der sich auch gegen mir versprochen in allem unterthenig und gehorsam zu seyn. Dargegen aber ich mich hinwider gegen ihme verspriche und verlobe, dass so 24 Jahr, von Dato dies Briefes an, herumb und fürober gelauften, er mit mir nach seiner Art und Weis, seines Gefallens, zu schalten, walten, regieren, führen, gut Macht haben solle, mit allen, es sey Leib, Seel, Fleisch, Blut und gut, und das in sein Ewigkeit. Hierauft absage ich allen denen, so da leben, allem Himmlischen Heer, und allen Menschen und das muss seyn.
Es gibt kein Gesetz, ausser tu was du willst.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book compiles a diverse range of operative magical practices, drawing heavily from traditional grimoire traditions (e.g., Key of Solomon, Herpentil's Black Magic), elemental magic, and demonology, while also acknowledging modern occult figures like Aleister Crowley and Anton LaVey. Its relevance lies in synthesizing historical magical systems into a practical manual, offering a comprehensive overview of ceremonial black magic from protective circles to complex spirit summonings and pacts. It provides both theoretical frameworks (hierarchies of spirits, types of magic) and detailed, step-by-step instructions for a wide array of rituals.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is explicitly defined in the introduction as 'those who seriously want to dedicate themselves to black magic' ('june, die sich ernsthaft der schwarzen Magie widmen wollen'). The author specifically warns away 'nervous, weak, hysterical, superstitious, and foolish people' ('nervösen, schwachen, hysterischen, abergläubischen und dummen Menschen'), indicating that the book is intended for individuals with a strong, unshrinking spirit capable of rigorously following potentially dangerous and complex occult procedures.
